Enable partially hardware accelerated GCM. GHASH calculation is still done
in software.

If MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_GCM is disabled and MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_AES is enabled then
mbedTLS will still use the hardware accelerated AES block operation, but
on a single block at a time.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_GCM
children.title: Enable partially hardware accelerated GCM

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated AES encryption & decryption.

Note that if the ESP32 CPU is running at 240MHz, hardware AES does not
offer any speed boost over software AES.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_AES
children.title: Enable hardware AES acceleration

children.help:
Use an interrupt to coordinate long MPI operations.

This allows other code to run on the CPU while an MPI operation is pending.
Otherwise the CPU busy-waits.
children.name: MBEDTLS_MPI_USE_INTERRUPT
children.title: Use interrupt for MPI exp-mod operations

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated multiple precision integer operations.

Hardware accelerated multiplication, modulo multiplication,
and modular exponentiation for up to SOC_RSA_MAX_BIT_LEN bit results.

These operations are used by RSA.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_MPI
children.title: Enable hardware MPI (bignum) acceleration

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated SHA1, SHA256, SHA384 & SHA512 in mbedTLS.

Due to a hardware limitation, on the ESP32 hardware acceleration is only
guaranteed if SHA digests are calculated one at a time. If more
than one SHA digest is calculated at the same time, one will
be calculated fully in hardware and the rest will be calculated
(at least partially calculated) in software. This happens automatically.

SHA hardware acceleration is faster than software in some situations but
slower in others. You should benchmark to find the best setting for you.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_SHA
children.title: Enable hardware SHA acceleration

children.help:
Fallback to software implementation of ECC point multiplication and point verification
for curves not supported in hardware.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECC_OTHER_CURVES_SOFT_FALLBACK
children.title: Fallback to software implementation for curves not supported in hardware

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated ECC point multiplication and point verification for points
on curve SECP192R1 and SECP256R1 in mbedTLS
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_ECC
children.title: Enable hardware ECC acceleration

children.help: Use ROM MD5 in mbedTLS.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ROM_MD5
children.title: Use MD5 implementation in ROM

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated ECDSA peripheral to sign data
on curve SECP192R1 and SECP256R1 in mbedTLS.

Note that for signing, the private key has to be burnt in an efuse key block
with key purpose set to ECDSA_KEY.
If no key is burnt, it will report an error

The key should be burnt in little endian format. espefuse.py utility handles it internally
but care needs to be taken while burning using esp_efuse APIs
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_ECDSA_SIGN
children.title: Enable ECDSA signing using on-chip ECDSA peripheral

children.help:
Enable hardware accelerated ECDSA peripheral to verify signature
on curve SECP192R1 and SECP256R1 in mbedTLS.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HARDWARE_ECDSA_VERIFY
children.title: Enable ECDSA signature verification using on-chip ECDSA peripheral

children.help:
This option enables hardware acceleration for ECDSA sign function, only
when using ATECC608A cryptoauth chip (integrated with ESP32-WROOM-32SE)
children.name: MBEDTLS_ATCA_HW_ECDSA_SIGN
children.title: Enable hardware ECDSA sign acceleration when using ATECC608A

children.help:
This option enables hardware acceleration for ECDSA sign function, only
when using ATECC608A cryptoauth chip (integrated with ESP32-WROOM-32SE)
children.name: MBEDTLS_ATCA_HW_ECDSA_VERIFY
children.title: Enable hardware ECDSA verify acceleration when using ATECC608A

children.help:
Enabling this config will provide users with a function
"mbedtls_platform_set_time()" that allows to set an alternative
time function pointer.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PLATFORM_TIME_ALT
children.title: Enable mbedtls time support: platform-specific

children.help:
Enables X.509 certificate expiry checks in mbedTLS.

If this option is disabled (default) then X.509 certificate
"valid from" and "valid to" timestamp fields are ignored.

If this option is enabled, these fields are compared with the
current system date and time. The time is retrieved using the
standard time() and gmtime() functions. If the certificate is not
valid for the current system time then verification will fail with
code MBEDTLS_X509_BADCERT_FUTURE or MBEDTLS_X509_BADCERT_EXPIRED.

Enabling this option requires adding functionality in the firmware
to set the system clock to a valid timestamp before using TLS. The
recommended way to do this is via ESP-IDF's SNTP functionality, but
any method can be used.

In the case where only a small number of certificates are trusted by
the device, please carefully consider the tradeoffs of enabling this
option. There may be undesired consequences, for example if all
trusted certificates expire while the device is offline and a TLS
connection is required to update. Or if an issue with the SNTP
server means that the system time is invalid for an extended period
after a reset.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME_DATE
children.title: Enable mbedtls certificate expiry check

children.help:
Enable use of time.h functions (time() and gmtime()) by mbedTLS.

This option doesn't require the system time to be correct, but enables
functionality that requires relative timekeeping - for example periodic
expiry of TLS session tickets or session cache entries.

Disabling this option will save some firmware size, particularly if
the rest of the firmware doesn't call any standard timekeeeping
functions.
children.name: MBEDTLS_HAVE_TIME
children.title: Enable mbedtls time support

children.help:
Standard ECDSA is "fragile" in the sense that lack of entropy when signing
may result in a compromise of the long-term signing key.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDSA_DETERMINISTIC
children.title: Enable deterministic ECDSA

children.help: Enable MBEDTLS_SHA512_C adds support for SHA-384 and SHA-512.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SHA512_C
children.title: Enable the SHA-384 and SHA-512 cryptographic hash algorithms

children.help:
mbedTLS can be compiled with protocol support for the TLS
server, TLS client, or both server and client.

Reducing the number of TLS roles supported saves code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_TLS_MODE
children.title: TLS Protocol Role

children.help: Enable to support symmetric key PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS key exchange modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_PSK
children.title: Enable PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_PSK
children.title: Enable DHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support Elliptic-Curve-Diffie-Hellman PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_PSK
children.title: Enable ECDHE-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support RSA PSK (pre-shared-key) TLS authentication modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA_PSK
children.title: Enable RSA-PSK based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show configuration for different types of pre-shared-key TLS authentatication methods.

Leaving this options disabled will save code size if they are not used.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PSK_MODES
children.title: Enable pre-shared-key ciphersuites

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_RSA
children.title: Enable RSA-only based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-DHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_DHE_RSA
children.title: Enable DHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDHE_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDHE-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_ECDSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-ECDSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECDHE-RSA-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECDH_RSA
children.title: Enable ECDH-RSA based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
Enable to show Elliptic Curve based ciphersuite mode options.

Disabling all Elliptic Curve ciphersuites saves code size and
can give slightly faster TLS handshakes, provided the server supports
RSA-only ciphersuite modes.
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ELLIPTIC_CURVE
children.title: Support Elliptic Curve based ciphersuites

children.help: Enable to support ciphersuites with prefix TLS-ECJPAKE-WITH-
children.name: MBEDTLS_KEY_EXCHANGE_ECJPAKE
children.title: Enable ECJPAKE based ciphersuite modes

children.help:
The two main uses of renegotiation are (1) refresh keys on long-lived
connections and (2) client authentication after the initial handshake.
If you don't need renegotiation, disabling it will save code size and
reduce the possibility of abuse/vulnerability.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_RENEGOTIATION
children.title: Support TLS renegotiation

children.help: Provisions for GM/T SSL 1.1 support
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_GMTSSL1_1
children.title: Support GM/T SSL 1.1 protocol

children.help: Requires TLS 1.2 to be enabled for DTLS 1.2
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_PROTO_DTLS
children.title: Support DTLS protocol (all versions)

children.help: Disabling this option will save some code size if it is not needed.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SSL_ALPN
children.title: Support ALPN (Application Layer Protocol Negotiation)

children.help:
Client support for RFC 5077 session tickets. See mbedTLS documentation for more details.
Disabling this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CLIENT_SSL_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: TLS: Client Support for RFC 5077 SSL session tickets

children.help:
Server support for RFC 5077 session tickets. See mbedTLS documentation for more details.
Disabling this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_SERVER_SSL_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: TLS: Server Support for RFC 5077 SSL session tickets

children.help:
Enables the DES block cipher to support 3DES-based TLS ciphersuites.

3DES is vulnerable to the Sweet32 attack and should only be enabled
if absolutely necessary.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DES_C
children.title: DES block cipher (legacy, insecure)

children.help:
Enables the Blowfish block cipher (not used for TLS sessions.)

The Blowfish cipher is not used for mbedTLS TLS sessions but can be
used for other purposes. Read up on the limitations of Blowfish (including
Sweet32) before enabling.
children.name: MBEDTLS_BLOWFISH_C
children.title: Blowfish block cipher (read help)

children.help: Enables the XTEA block cipher.
children.name: MBEDTLS_XTEA_C
children.title: XTEA block cipher

children.help:
Enable Counter with CBC-MAC (CCM) modes for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CCM_C
children.title: CCM (Counter with CBC-MAC) block cipher modes

children.help:
Enable Galois/Counter Mode for AES and/or Camellia ciphers.

This option is generally faster than CCM.
children.name: MBEDTLS_GCM_C
children.title: GCM (Galois/Counter) block cipher modes

children.help: Enable NIST key wrapping and key wrapping padding.
children.name: MBEDTLS_NIST_KW_C
children.title: NIST key wrapping (KW) and KW padding (KWP)

children.help: Enable the RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_RIPEMD160_C
children.title: Enable RIPEMD-160 hash algorithm

children.help:
Enable decoding/parsing of PEM formatted certificates.

If your certificates are all in the simpler DER format, disabling
this option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_PARSE_C
children.title: Read & Parse PEM formatted certificates

children.help:
Enable writing of PEM formatted certificates.

If writing certificate data only in DER format, disabling this
option will save some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_PEM_WRITE_C
children.title: Write PEM formatted certificates

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Revocation Lists.
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CRL_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CRL parsing

children.help: Support for parsing X.509 Certifificate Signing Requests
children.name: MBEDTLS_X509_CSR_PARSE_C
children.title: X.509 CSR parsing

children.help:
Enable DHM. Needed to use DHE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.

Note that the security of Diffie-Hellman key exchanges depends on
a suitable prime being used for the exchange. Please see detailed
warning text about this in file `mbedtls/dhm.h` file.
children.name: MBEDTLS_DHM_C
children.title: Diffie-Hellman-Merkle key exchange (DHM)

children.help: Enable ECDSA. Needed to use ECDSA-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDSA_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve DSA

children.help: Enable ECDH. Needed to use ECDHE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECDH_C
children.title: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)

children.help: Enable ECJPAKE. Needed to use ECJPAKE-xxx TLS ciphersuites.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECJPAKE_C
children.title: Elliptic curve J-PAKE

children.help: Enable support for SECP192R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP384R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP384R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP521R1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP521R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP521R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP192K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP192K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP192K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP224K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP224K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP224K1 curve

children.help: Enable support for SECP256K1 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256K1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable SECP256K1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP256R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP256R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP384R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP384R1 curve

children.help: support for DP Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_BP512R1_ENABLED
children.title: Enable BP512R1 curve

children.help: Enable support for CURVE25519 Elliptic Curve.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_CURVE25519_ENABLED
children.title: Enable CURVE25519 curve

children.help:
NIST 'modulo p' optimisations increase Elliptic Curve operation performance.

Disabling this option saves some code size.
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_NIST_OPTIM
children.title: NIST 'modulo p' optimisations

children.help:
This configuration option enables optimizations to speedup (about 3 ~ 4 times) the ECP
fixed point multiplication using pre-computed tables in the flash memory.
Disabling this configuration option saves flash footprint (about 29KB if all Elliptic Curve selected)
in the application binary.

# end of Elliptic Curve options
children.name: MBEDTLS_ECP_FIXED_POINT_OPTIM
children.title: Enable fixed-point multiplication optimisations

children.help: Enable support for Poly1305 MAC algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_POLY1305_C
children.title: Poly1305 MAC algorithm

children.help: Enable support for ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD algorithm.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CHACHAPOLY_C
children.title: ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD algorithm

children.help: Enable support for Chacha20 stream cipher.
children.name: MBEDTLS_CHACHA20_C
children.title: Chacha20 stream cipher

children.help:
Enable support for the Hashed Message Authentication Code
(HMAC)-based key derivation function (HKDF).
children.name: MBEDTLS_HKDF_C
children.title: HKDF algorithm (RFC 5869)

children.help: Enable threading alt to allow your own alternate threading implementation.
children.name: MBEDTLS_THREADING_ALT
children.title: Enable threading alternate implementation

children.help: Enable the pthread wrapper layer for the threading layer.
children.name: MBEDTLS_THREADING_PTHREAD
children.title: Enable threading pthread implementation

children.help:
If you do intend to use contexts between threads, you will need to enable
this layer to prevent race conditions.
children.name: MBEDTLS_THREADING_C
children.title: Enable the threading abstraction layer

children.help:
Fallback to software implementation for RSA key lengths
larger than SOC_RSA_MAX_BIT_LEN. If this is not active
then the ESP will be unable to process keys greater
than SOC_RSA_MAX_BIT_LEN.
children.name: MBEDTLS_LARGE_KEY_SOFTWARE_MPI
children.title: Fallback to software implementation for larger MPI values

children.help: If not, this library will use MQTT protocol 3.1
children.name: MQTT_PROTOCOL_311
children.title: Enable MQTT protocol 3.1.1

children.help: If not, this library will not support MQTT 5.0
children.name: MQTT_PROTOCOL_5
children.title: Enable MQTT protocol 5.0

children.help: Enable MQTT transport over SSL with mbedtls
children.name: MQTT_TRANSPORT_SSL
children.title: Enable MQTT over SSL

children.help: Enable MQTT transport over Websocket Secure.
children.name: MQTT_TRANSPORT_WEBSOCKET_SECURE
children.title: Enable MQTT over Websocket Secure

children.help: Enable MQTT transport over Websocket.
children.name: MQTT_TRANSPORT_WEBSOCKET
children.title: Enable MQTT over Websocket

children.help:
Set this to true for the message id (2.3.1 Packet Identifier) to be generated
as an incremental number rather then a random value (used by default)
children.name: MQTT_MSG_ID_INCREMENTAL
children.title: Use Incremental Message Id

children.help:
Set this to true to avoid publishing (enqueueing messages) if the client is disconnected.
The MQTT client tries to publish all messages by default, even in the disconnected state
(where the qos1 and qos2 packets are stored in the internal outbox to be published later)
The MQTT_SKIP_PUBLISH_IF_DISCONNECTED option allows applications to override this behaviour
and not enqueue publish packets in the disconnected state.
children.name: MQTT_SKIP_PUBLISH_IF_DISCONNECTED
children.title: Skip publish if disconnected

children.help:
Set this to true to post events for all messages which were deleted from the outbox
before being correctly sent and confirmed.
children.name: MQTT_REPORT_DELETED_MESSAGES
children.title: Report deleted messages

children.help: Default MQTT over TCP port
children.name: MQTT_TCP_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over TCP port

children.help: Default MQTT over SSL port
children.name: MQTT_SSL_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over SSL port

children.help: Default MQTT over Websocket port
children.name: MQTT_WS_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over Websocket port

children.help: Default MQTT over Websocket Secure port
children.name: MQTT_WSS_DEFAULT_PORT
children.title: Default MQTT over Websocket Secure port

children.help: This buffer size using for both transmit and receive
children.name: MQTT_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: Default MQTT Buffer Size

children.help: MQTT task stack size
children.name: MQTT_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: MQTT task stack size

children.help:
Default config employs API locks to protect internal structures. It is possible to disable
these locks if the user code doesn't access MQTT API from multiple concurrent tasks
children.name: MQTT_DISABLE_API_LOCKS
children.title: Disable API locks

children.help: MQTT task priority. Higher number denotes higher priority.
children.name: MQTT_TASK_PRIORITY
children.title: MQTT task priority

children.help: Timeout when polling underlying transport for read.
children.name: MQTT_POLL_READ_TIMEOUT_MS
children.title: MQTT transport poll read timeut

children.help: A value higher than 1 enables multiple queued events.
children.name: MQTT_EVENT_QUEUE_SIZE
children.title: Number of queued events.

children.help: Custom MQTT configurations.
children.name: MQTT_USE_CUSTOM_CONFIG
children.title: MQTT Using custom configurations

children.help: This will enable core selection
children.name: MQTT_TASK_CORE_SELECTION_ENABLED
children.title: Enable MQTT task core selection

children.help: Set to true to use external memory for outbox data.
children.name: MQTT_OUTBOX_DATA_ON_EXTERNAL_MEMORY
children.title: Use external memory for outbox data

children.help:
Set to true if a specific implementation of message outbox is needed (e.g. persistent outbox in NVM or
similar).
Note: Implementation of the custom outbox must be added to the mqtt component. These CMake commands
could be used to append the custom implementation to lib-mqtt sources:
idf_component_get_property(mqtt mqtt COMPONENT_LIB)
set_property(TARGET ${mqtt} PROPERTY SOURCES ${PROJECT_DIR}/custom_outbox.c APPEND)
children.name: MQTT_CUSTOM_OUTBOX
children.title: Enable custom outbox implementation

children.help: Messages which stays in the outbox longer than this value before being published will be discarded.
children.name: MQTT_OUTBOX_EXPIRED_TIMEOUT_MS
children.title: Outbox message expired timeout[ms]

children.help:
This option allows configuring the desired line endings sent to UART
when a newline ('\n', LF) appears on stdout.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: whenever LF is encountered, prepend it with CR

LF: no modification is applied, stdout is sent as is

CR: each occurence of LF is replaced with CR

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDOUT_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART output

children.help:
This option allows configuring which input sequence on UART produces
a newline ('\n', LF) on stdin.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: CRLF is converted to LF

LF: no modification is applied, input is sent to stdin as is

CR: each occurence of CR is replaced with LF

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDIN_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART input

children.help:
In most chips the ROM contains parts of newlib C library, including printf/scanf family
of functions. These functions have been compiled with so-called "nano"
formatting option. This option doesn't support 64-bit integer formats and C99
features, such as positional arguments.

For more details about "nano" formatting option, please see newlib readme file,
search for '--enable-newlib-nano-formatted-io':
https://sourceware.org/newlib/README

If this option is enabled and the ROM contains functions from newlib-nano, the build system
will use functions available in ROM, reducing the application binary size.
Functions available in ROM run faster than functions which run from flash. Functions available
in ROM can also run when flash instruction cache is disabled.

Some chips (e.g. ESP32-C6) has the full formatting versions of printf/scanf in ROM instead of
the nano versions and in this building with newlib nano might actually increase the size of
the binary. Which functions are present in ROM can be seen from ROM caps:
ESP_ROM_HAS_NEWLIB_NANO_FORMAT and ESP_ROM_HAS_NEWLIB_NORMAL_FORMAT.

If you need 64-bit integer formatting support or C99 features, keep this
option disabled.
children.name: NEWLIB_NANO_FORMAT
children.title: Enable 'nano' formatting options for printf/scanf family

children.help:
This setting defines which hardware timers are used to
implement 'gettimeofday' and 'time' functions in C library.

- If both high-resolution (systimer for all targets except ESP32)
    and RTC timers are used, timekeeping will continue in deep sleep.
    Time will be reported at 1 microsecond resolution.
    This is the default, and the recommended option.
- If only high-resolution timer (systimer) is used, gettimeofday will
    provide time at microsecond resolution.
    Time will not be preserved when going into deep sleep mode.
- If only RTC timer is used, timekeeping will continue in
    deep sleep, but time will be measured at 6.(6) microsecond
    resolution. Also the gettimeofday function itself may take
    longer to run.
- If no timers are used, gettimeofday and time functions
    return -1 and set errno to ENOSYS.
- When RTC is used for timekeeping, two RTC_STORE registers are
    used to keep time in deep sleep mode.
children.name: NEWLIB_TIME_SYSCALL
children.title: Timers used for gettimeofday function

children.help:
This option enables encryption for NVS. When enabled, AES-XTS is used to encrypt
the complete NVS data, except the page headers. It requires XTS encryption keys
to be stored in an encrypted partition. This means enabling flash encryption is
a pre-requisite for this feature.
children.name: NVS_ENCRYPTION
children.title: Enable NVS encryption

children.help:
Enabling this will ignore "encrypted" flag for NVS partitions. NVS encryption
scheme is different than hardware flash encryption and hence it is not recommended
to have "encrypted" flag for NVS partitions. This was not being checked in pre v4.3
IDF. Hence, if you have any devices where this flag is kept enabled in partition
table then enabling this config will allow to have same behavior as pre v4.3 IDF.
children.name: NVS_COMPATIBLE_PRE_V4_3_ENCRYPTION_FLAG
children.title: NVS partition encrypted flag compatible with ESP-IDF before v4.3

children.help: This option switches error checking type between assertions (y) or return codes (n).
children.name: NVS_ASSERT_ERROR_CHECK
children.title: Use assertions for error checking

children.help: Select this option to enable dynamic log level control for OpenThread
children.name: OPENTHREAD_LOG_LEVEL_DYNAMIC
children.title: Enable dynamic log level control

children.name: OPENTHREAD_CONSOLE_TYPE_USB_SERIAL_JTAG
children.title: OpenThread console type USB Serial/JTAG Controller

children.help: Select OpenThread console type
children.name: OPENTHREAD_CONSOLE_TYPE
children.title: OpenThread console type

children.help: Select OpenThread log level.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_LOG_LEVEL
children.title: OpenThread log verbosity

children.help: Select this option to enable OpenThread and show the submenu with OpenThread configuration choices.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_ENABLED
children.title: OpenThread

children.help:
A string in the format "<address>/<plen>", where `<address>` is an IPv6
address and `<plen>` is a prefix length. For example "fd00:db8:a0:0::/64"
children.name: OPENTHREAD_MESH_LOCAL_PREFIX
children.title: OpenThread mesh local prefix, format <address>/<plen>

children.help: The OpenThread network extended pan id in hex string format
children.name: OPENTHREAD_NETWORK_EXTPANID
children.title: OpenThread extended pan id

children.help: The OpenThread network network key in hex string format
children.name: OPENTHREAD_NETWORK_MASTERKEY
children.title: OpenThread network key

children.help: The OpenThread pre-shared commissioner key in hex string format
children.name: OPENTHREAD_NETWORK_PSKC
children.title: OpenThread pre-shared commissioner key

children.help: Select this to use the native 15.4 radio.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_NATIVE
children.title: Native 15.4 radio

children.help: Select this to connect to a Radio Co-Processor via UART.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_SPINEL_UART
children.title: Connect via UART

children.help: Select this to connect to a Radio Co-Processor via SPI.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_SPINEL_SPI
children.title: Connect via SPI

children.help: Configure how OpenThread connects to the 15.4 radio
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO_TYPE
children.title: Config the Thread radio type

children.help: Select this to enable Full Thread Device which can act as router and leader in a Thread network.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_FTD
children.title: Full Thread Device

children.help:
Select this to enable Minimal Thread Device which can only act as end device in a Thread network.
This will reduce the code size of the OpenThread stack.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_MTD
children.title: Minimal Thread Device

children.help:
Select this to enable Radio Only Device which can only forward 15.4 packets to the host.
The OpenThread stack will be run on the host and OpenThread will have minimal footprint on the
radio only device.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RADIO
children.title: Radio Only Device

children.help: OpenThread can be configured to different device types (FTD, MTD, Radio)
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DEVICE_TYPE
children.title: Config the Thread device type

children.help: Select this to enable UART connection to host.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RCP_UART
children.title: UART RCP

children.help: Select this to enable SPI connection to host.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_RCP_SPI
children.title: SPI RCP

children.help: Select this option to enable Command-Line Interface in OpenThread.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_CLI
children.title: Enable Openthread Command-Line Interface

children.help:
Select this option to enable Diag in OpenThread. This will enable diag mode and a series of diag commands
in the OpenThread command line. These commands allow users to manipulate low-level features of the storage
and 15.4 radio.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DIAG
children.title: Enable diag

children.name: OPENTHREAD_COMM_MAX_JOINER_ENTRIES
children.title: The size of max commissioning joiner entries

children.help:
Select this option to enable commissioner in OpenThread. This will enable the device to act as a
commissioner in the Thread network. A commissioner checks the pre-shared key from a joining device with
the Thread commissioning protocol and shares the network parameter with the joining device upon success.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_COMMISSIONER
children.title: Enable Commissioner

children.help:
Select this option to enable Joiner in OpenThread. This allows a device to join the Thread network with a
pre-shared key using the Thread commissioning protocol.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_JOINER
children.title: Enable Joiner

children.help: Set the max buffer size of service entries in the SRP client service pool.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_SRP_CLIENT_MAX_SERVICES
children.title: Specifies number of service entries in the SRP client service pool

children.help:
Select this option to enable SRP Client in OpenThread. This allows a device to register SRP services to SRP
Server.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_SRP_CLIENT
children.title: Enable SRP Client

children.help: Select this option to enable DNS Client in OpenThread.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DNS_CLIENT
children.title: Enable DNS Client

children.help: Select this option to enable border router features in OpenThread.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_BORDER_ROUTER
children.title: Enable Border Router

children.help: If enabled, the message pool is managed by platform defined logic.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_PLATFORM_MSGPOOL_MANAGEMENT
children.title: Allocate message pool buffer from PSRAM

children.name: OPENTHREAD_NUM_MESSAGE_BUFFERS
children.title: The number of openthread message buffers

children.name: OPENTHREAD_SPINEL_RX_FRAME_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: The size of openthread spinel rx frame buffer

children.name: OPENTHREAD_MLE_MAX_CHILDREN
children.title: The size of max MLE children entries

children.name: OPENTHREAD_TMF_ADDR_CACHE_ENTRIES
children.title: The size of max TMF address cache entries

children.help: Set the DNS server IPv4 address.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DNS_SERVER_ADDR
children.title: DNS server address (IPv4)

children.help: Select this option to acquire NAT64 address from dns servers.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DNS64_CLIENT
children.title: Use dns64 client

children.help: Set the OpenThread UART buffer size.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_UART_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: The uart received buffer size of openthread

children.help: Select this option to enable link metrics feature
children.name: OPENTHREAD_LINK_METRICS
children.title: Enable link metrics feature

children.help: Select this option to enable mac filter feature
children.name: OPENTHREAD_MACFILTER_ENABLE
children.title: Enable mac filter feature

children.help: Select this option to enable CSL feature
children.name: OPENTHREAD_CSL_ENABLE
children.title: Enable CSL feature

children.help: The device's XTAL accuracy, in ppm.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_XTAL_ACCURACY
children.title: The accuracy of the XTAL

children.help: The current accuracy of the clock used for scheduling CSL operations
children.name: OPENTHREAD_CSL_ACCURACY
children.title: The current CSL rx/tx scheduling drift, in units of ± ppm

children.help: The fixed uncertainty of the Device for scheduling CSL Transmissions in units of 10 microseconds.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_CSL_UNCERTAIN
children.title: The CSL Uncertainty in units of 10 us.

children.help: Select this option to set rx on when sleep in CSL feature, only for debug
children.name: OPENTHREAD_CSL_DEBUG_ENABLE
children.title: Enable CSL debug

children.help: Only used for Thread1.2 certification
children.name: OPENTHREAD_DUA_ENABLE
children.title: Enable Domain Unicast Address feature

children.help:
Select this option to enable time synchronization feature, the devices in the same Thread network could
sync to the same network time.
children.name: OPENTHREAD_TIME_SYNC
children.title: Enable the time synchronization service feature

children.help:
Enable support of security version 0.
Disabling this option saves some code size.
Consult the Enabling protocomm security version section of the
Protocomm documentation in ESP-IDF Programming guide for more details.
children.name: ESP_PROTOCOMM_SUPPORT_SECURITY_VERSION_0
children.title: Support protocomm security version 0 (no security)

children.help:
Enable support of security version 1.
Disabling this option saves some code size.
Consult the Enabling protocomm security version section of the
Protocomm documentation in ESP-IDF Programming guide for more details.
children.name: ESP_PROTOCOMM_SUPPORT_SECURITY_VERSION_1
children.title: Support protocomm security version 1 (Curve25519 key exchange + AES-CTR encryption/decryption)

children.help:
Enable support of security version 2.
Disabling this option saves some code size.
Consult the Enabling protocomm security version section of the
Protocomm documentation in ESP-IDF Programming guide for more details.
children.name: ESP_PROTOCOMM_SUPPORT_SECURITY_VERSION_2
children.title: Support protocomm security version 2 (SRP6a-based key exchange + AES-GCM encryption/decryption)

children.help: Keep BT on after calling protocomm_ble_stop
children.name: ESP_PROTOCOMM_KEEP_BLE_ON_AFTER_BLE_STOP

children.help: Terminate connection after calling protocomm_ble_stop
children.name: ESP_PROTOCOMM_DISCONNECT_AFTER_BLE_STOP

children.help: Priority used to create new tasks with default pthread parameters.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_PRIO_DEFAULT
children.title: Default task priority

children.help: Stack size used to create new tasks with default pthread parameters.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT
children.title: Default task stack size

children.help: Minimum allowed pthread stack size set in attributes passed to pthread_create
children.name: PTHREAD_STACK_MIN
children.title: Minimum allowed pthread stack size

children.help: The default core to which pthreads are pinned.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_CORE_DEFAULT
children.title: Default pthread core affinity

children.help: The default name of pthreads.
children.name: PTHREAD_TASK_NAME_DEFAULT
children.title: Default name of pthreads

children.help:
If this option is enabled, if SPI flash write verification fails then a log error line
will be written with the address, expected & actual values. This can be useful when
debugging hardware SPI flash problems.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_LOG_FAILED_WRITE
children.title: Log errors if verification fails

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any SPI flash write which tries to set zero bits in the flash to
ones will log a warning. Such writes will not result in the requested data appearing identically
in flash once written, as SPI NOR flash can only set bits to one when an entire sector is erased.
After erasing, individual bits can only be written from one to zero.

Note that some software (such as SPIFFS) which is aware of SPI NOR flash may write one bits as an
optimisation, relying on the data in flash becoming a bitwise AND of the new data and any existing data.
Such software will log spurious warnings if this option is enabled.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WARN_SETTING_ZERO_TO_ONE
children.title: Log warning if writing zero bits to ones

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any time SPI flash is written then the data will be read
back and verified. This can catch hardware problems with SPI flash, or flash which
was not erased before verification.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_VERIFY_WRITE
children.title: Verify SPI flash writes

children.help:
This option enables the following APIs:

- esp_flash_reset_counters
- esp_flash_dump_counters
- esp_flash_get_counters

These APIs may be used to collect performance data for spi_flash APIs
and to help understand behaviour of libraries which use SPI flash.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ENABLE_COUNTERS
children.title: Enable operation counters

children.help:
Enable this flag to use patched versions of SPI flash ROM driver functions.
This option should be enabled, if any one of the following is true: (1) need to write
to flash on ESP32-D2WD; (2) main SPI flash is connected to non-default pins; (3) main
SPI flash chip is manufactured by ISSI.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_DRIVER_PATCH
children.title: Enable SPI flash ROM driver patched functions

children.help:
Enable this flag to use new SPI flash driver functions from ROM instead of ESP-IDF.

If keeping this as "n" in your project, you will have less free IRAM.
But you can use all of our flash features.

If making this as "y" in your project, you will increase free IRAM.
But you may miss out on some flash features and support for new flash chips.

Currently the ROM cannot support the following features:

- SPI_FLASH_AUTO_SUSPEND (C3, S3)
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_IMPL
children.title: Use esp_flash implementation in ROM

children.help:
SPI flash APIs can optionally abort or return a failure code
if erasing or writing addresses that fall at the beginning
of flash (covering the bootloader and partition table) or that
overlap the app partition that contains the running app.

It is not recommended to ever write to these regions from an IDF app,
and this check prevents logic errors or corrupted firmware memory from
damaging these regions.

Note that this feature *does not* check calls to the esp_rom_xxx SPI flash
ROM functions. These functions should not be called directly from IDF
applications.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_DANGEROUS_WRITE
children.title: Writing to dangerous flash regions

children.help:
Each SPI bus needs a lock for arbitration among devices. This allows multiple
devices on a same bus, but may reduce the speed of esp_flash driver access to the
main flash chip.

If you only need to use esp_flash driver to access the main flash chip, disable
this option, and the lock will be bypassed on SPI1 bus. Otherwise if extra devices
are needed to attach to SPI1 bus, enable this option.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SHARE_SPI1_BUS
children.title: Support other devices attached to SPI1 bus

children.help:
Some flash chips can have very high "max" erase times, especially for block erase (32KB or 64KB).
This option allows to bypass "block erase" and always do sector erase commands.
This will be much slower overall in most cases, but improves latency for other code to run.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_BYPASS_BLOCK_ERASE
children.title: Bypass a block erase and always do sector erase

children.help:
If a duration of one erase command is large
then it will yield CPUs after finishing a current command.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_DURATION_MS
children.title: Duration of erasing to yield CPUs (ms)

children.help: Defines how many ticks will be before returning to continue a erasing.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_TICKS
children.title: CPU release time (tick) for an erase operation

children.help:
This allows to yield the CPUs between erase commands.
Prevents starvation of other tasks.
Please use this configuration together with ``SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_DURATION_MS`` and
``SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_TICKS`` after carefully checking flash datasheet to avoid a
watchdog timeout.
For more information, please check `SPI Flash API` reference documenation
under section `OS Function`.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_YIELD_DURING_ERASE
children.title: Enables yield operation during flash erase

children.help:
This option is default n before ESP32-C3, because it needs bootloader support.

CAUTION: If you want to OTA to an app with this feature turned on, please make
sure the bootloader has the support for it. (later than IDF v4.3)

Auto-suspend feature only supported by XMC chip.
If you are using an official module, please contact Espressif Business support.
Also reading auto suspend part in `SPI Flash API` document before you enable this function.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_AUTO_SUSPEND
children.title: Auto suspend long erase/write operations (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
Flash write is broken down in terms of multiple (smaller) write operations.
This configuration options helps to set individual write chunk size, smaller
value here ensures that cache (and non-IRAM resident interrupts) remains
disabled for shorter duration.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WRITE_CHUNK_SIZE
children.title: Flash write chunk size

children.help:
SPI Flash driver uses the flash size configured in bootloader header by default.
Enable this option to override flash size with latest ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE value from
the app header if the size in the bootloader header is incorrect.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SIZE_OVERRIDE
children.title: Override flash size in bootloader header by ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE

children.help: This option is helpful if you are using a flash chip whose timeout is quite large or unpredictable.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_CHECK_ERASE_TIMEOUT_DISABLED
children.title: Flash timeout checkout disabled

children.help:
This option allows the chip driver list to be customized, instead of using the default list provided by
ESP-IDF.

When this option is enabled, the default list is no longer compiled or linked. Instead, the
`default_registered_chips` structure must be provided by the user.

See example: custom_chip_driver under examples/storage for more details.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_OVERRIDE_CHIP_DRIVER_LIST
children.title: Override default chip driver list

children.help:
When this option is selected, the patch will be enabled for XMC.
Follow the recommended flow by XMC for better stability.

DO NOT DISABLE UNLESS YOU KNOW WHAT YOU ARE DOING.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_BROWNOUT_RESET_XMC
children.title: Enable sending reset when brownout for XMC flash chips

children.help:
When brownout happens during flash erase/write operations,
send reset command to stop the flash operations to improve stability.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_BROWNOUT_RESET

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of ISSI chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_ISSI_CHIP
children.title: ISSI

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of MXIC chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_MXIC_CHIP
children.title: MXIC

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of GD (GigaDevice) chips if chip vendor not
directly given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. If you are using Wrover
modules, please don't disable this, otherwise your flash may not work in 4-bit
mode.

This adds support for variant chips, however will extend detecting time and image
size. Note that the default chip driver supports the GD chips with product ID
60H.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_GD_CHIP
children.title: GigaDevice

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of Winbond chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_WINBOND_CHIP
children.title: Winbond

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of BOYA chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_BOYA_CHIP
children.title: BOYA

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of TH chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_TH_CHIP
children.title: TH

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of Octal MXIC chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_MXIC_OPI_CHIP
children.title: mxic (opi)

children.help:
This option enables flash read/write operations to encrypted partition/s. This option
is kept enabled irrespective of state of flash encryption feature. However, in case
application is not using flash encryption feature and is in need of some additional
memory from IRAM region (~1KB) then this config can be disabled.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ENABLE_ENCRYPTED_READ_WRITE
children.title: Enable encrypted partition read/write operations

children.help:
This option is invisible, and will be selected automatically
when ``ESPTOOLPY_FLASHFREQ_120M`` is selected.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_HPM_ENABLE

children.help: Define maximum number of partitions that can be mounted.
children.name: SPIFFS_MAX_PARTITIONS
children.title: Maximum Number of Partitions

children.help: Enables memory write caching for file descriptors in hydrogen.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE_WR
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Write Caching

children.help: Enable/disable statistics on caching. Debug/test purpose only.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE_STATS
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Cache Statistics

children.help:
Enables/disable memory read caching of nucleus file system
operations.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Cache

children.help:
Always check header of each accessed page to ensure consistent state.
If enabled it will increase number of reads from flash, especially
if cache is disabled.
children.name: SPIFFS_PAGE_CHECK
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Page Check

children.help: Define maximum number of GC runs to perform to reach desired free pages.
children.name: SPIFFS_GC_MAX_RUNS
children.title: Set Maximum GC Runs

children.help: Enable/disable statistics on gc. Debug/test purpose only.
children.name: SPIFFS_GC_STATS
children.title: Enable SPIFFS GC Statistics

children.help:
Logical page size of SPIFFS partition, in bytes. Must be multiple
of flash page size (which is usually 256 bytes).
Larger page sizes reduce overhead when storing large files, and
improve filesystem performance when reading large files.
Smaller page sizes reduce overhead when storing small (< page size)
files.
children.name: SPIFFS_PAGE_SIZE
children.title: SPIFFS logical page size

children.help:
Object name maximum length. Note that this length include the
zero-termination character, meaning maximum string of characters
can at most be SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN - 1.

SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN + SPIFFS_META_LENGTH should not exceed
SPIFFS_PAGE_SIZE - 64.
children.name: SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN
children.title: Set SPIFFS Maximum Name Length

children.help:
If this option is enabled, symbolic links are taken into account
during partition image creation.
children.name: SPIFFS_FOLLOW_SYMLINKS
children.title: Enable symbolic links for image creation

children.help:
If this option is enabled, the magic will also be dependent
on the length of the filesystem. For example, a filesystem
configured and formatted for 4 megabytes will not be accepted
for mounting with a configuration defining the filesystem as 2 megabytes.
children.name: SPIFFS_USE_MAGIC_LENGTH
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Length Magic

children.help:
Enable this to have an identifiable spiffs filesystem.
This will look for a magic in all sectors to determine if this
is a valid spiffs system or not at mount time.
children.name: SPIFFS_USE_MAGIC
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Magic

children.help:
This option sets the number of extra bytes stored in the file header.
These bytes can be used in an application-specific manner.
Set this to at least 4 bytes to enable support for saving file
modification time.

SPIFFS_OBJ_NAME_LEN + SPIFFS_META_LENGTH should not exceed
SPIFFS_PAGE_SIZE - 64.
children.name: SPIFFS_META_LENGTH
children.title: Size of per-file metadata field

children.help:
If enabled, then the first 4 bytes of per-file metadata will be used
to store file modification time (mtime), accessible through
stat/fstat functions.
Modification time is updated when the file is opened.
children.name: SPIFFS_USE_MTIME
children.title: Save file modification time

children.help:
If this option is not set, the time field is 32 bits (up to 2106 year),
otherwise it is 64 bits and make sure it matches SPIFFS_META_LENGTH.
If the chip already has the spiffs image with the time field = 32 bits
then this option cannot be applied in this case.
Erase it first before using this option.
To resolve the Y2K38 problem for the spiffs, use a toolchain with
64-bit time_t support.
children.name: SPIFFS_MTIME_WIDE_64_BITS
children.title: The time field occupies 64 bits in the image instead of 32 bits

children.help: Enabling this option will print general debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_DBG
children.title: Enable general SPIFFS debug

children.help: Enabling this option will print API debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_API_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS API debug

children.help: Enabling this option will print GC debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_GC_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Garbage Cleaner debug

children.help: Enabling this option will print cache debug mesages to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_CACHE_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Cache debug

children.help:
Enabling this option will print Filesystem Check debug mesages
to the console.
children.name: SPIFFS_CHECK_DBG
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Check debug

children.help: Enable this option to enable SPIFFS_vis function in the API.
children.name: SPIFFS_TEST_VISUALISATION
children.title: Enable SPIFFS Filesystem Visualization

children.help: Size of the buffer used for constructing the HTTP Upgrade request during connect
children.name: WS_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: Websocket transport buffer size

children.help:
If enable this option, websocket transport buffer will be freed after connection
succeed to save more heap.
children.name: WS_DYNAMIC_BUFFER
children.title: Using dynamic websocket transport buffer

children.help: Enable support for creating websocket transport.
children.name: WS_TRANSPORT
children.title: Enable Websocket Transport

children.help: Choose the ULP Coprocessor type: ULP FSM (Finite State Machine) or ULP RISC-V.
children.name: ULP_COPROC_TYPE
children.title: ULP Co-processor type

children.help:
Bytes of memory to reserve for ULP Co-processor firmware & data.
Data is reserved at the beginning of RTC slow memory.
children.name: ULP_COPROC_RESERVE_MEM
children.title: RTC slow memory reserved for coprocessor

children.help:
Enable this feature if you plan to use the ULP Co-processor.
Once this option is enabled, further ULP co-processor configuration will appear in the menu.
children.name: ULP_COPROC_ENABLED
children.title: Enable Ultra Low Power (ULP) Co-processor

children.help:
The accuracy of the bitbanged UART driver is limited, it is not
recommend to increase the value above 19200.
children.name: ULP_RISCV_UART_BAUDRATE
children.title: Baudrate used by the bitbanged ULP RISC-V UART driver

children.help:
Set the ULP RISC-V I2C read/write timeout. Set this value to -1
if the ULP RISC-V I2C read and write APIs should wait forever.
Please note that the tick rate of the ULP co-processor would be
different than the OS tick rate of the main core and therefore
can have different timeout value depending on which core the API
is invoked on.
children.name: ULP_RISCV_I2C_RW_TIMEOUT
children.title: Set timeout for ULP RISC-V I2C transaction timeout in ticks.

children.help:
Size of the shared memory defined in ulp_lp_core_memory_shared.c.
Size should be kept in-sync with the size of the struct defined there.
children.name: ULP_SHARED_MEM

children.help: If not set, assertions on float arguments will not be available.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_FLOAT
children.title: Support for float type

children.help: If not set, assertions on double arguments will not be available.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_DOUBLE
children.title: Support for double type

children.help:
If not set, assertions on 64-bit integer types will always fail.
If this feature is enabled, take care not to pass pointers (which are 32 bit)
to UNITY_ASSERT_EQUAL, as that will cause pointer-to-int-cast warnings.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_64BIT
children.title: Support for 64-bit integer types

children.help: If set, Unity will colorize test results using console escape sequences.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_COLOR
children.title: Colorize test output

children.help:
If set, then the following features will be available:

- TEST_CASE macro which performs automatic registration of test functions
- Functions to run registered test functions: unity_run_all_tests,
  unity_run_tests_with_filter, unity_run_single_test_by_name.
- Interactive menu which lists test cases and allows choosing the tests to
  be run, available via unity_run_menu function.

Disable if a different test registration mechanism is used.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_IDF_TEST_RUNNER
children.title: Include ESP-IDF test registration/running helpers

children.help:
If set, unity_fixture.h header file and associated source files are part of
the build. These provide an optional set of macros and functions to
implement test groups.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_FIXTURE
children.title: Include Unity test fixture

children.help:
If set, the unity framework will print the backtrace information before
jumping back to the test menu. The jumping is usually occurs in assert
functions such as TEST_ASSERT, TEST_FAIL etc.
children.name: UNITY_ENABLE_BACKTRACE_ON_FAIL
children.title: Print a backtrace when a unit test fails

children.help:
Each USB device attached is allocated a dedicated buffer for its OUT/IN transfers to/from the device's
control endpoint. The maximum size of that buffer is determined by this option. The limited size of the
transfer buffer have the following implications:
- The maximum length of control transfers is limited
- Device's with configuration descriptors larger than this limit cannot be supported
children.name: USB_HOST_CONTROL_TRANSFER_MAX_SIZE
children.title: Largest size (in bytes) of transfers to/from default endpoints

children.help:
The underlying hardware has size adjustable FIFOs to cache USB packets on reception (IN) or for
transmission (OUT). The size of these FIFOs will affect the largest MPS (maximum packet size) and the
maximum number of packets that can be cached at any one time. The hardware contains the following
FIFOS: RX (for all IN packets), Non-periodic TX (for Bulk and Control OUT packets), and Periodic TX
(for Interrupt and Isochronous OUT packets). This configuration option allows biasing the FIFO sizes
towards a particular use case, which may be necessary for devices that have endpoints with large MPS.
The MPS limits for each biasing are listed below:

Balanced:
- IN (all transfer types), 408 bytes
- OUT non-periodic (Bulk/Control), 192 bytes (i.e., 3 x 64 byte packets)
- OUT periodic (Interrupt/Isochronous), 192 bytes

Bias IN:
- IN (all transfer types), 600 bytes
- OUT non-periodic (Bulk/Control), 64 bytes (i.e., 1 x 64 byte packets)
- OUT periodic (Interrupt/Isochronous), 128 bytes

Bias Periodic OUT:
- IN (all transfer types), 128 bytes
- OUT non-periodic (Bulk/Control), 64 bytes (i.e., 1 x 64 byte packets)
- OUT periodic (Interrupt/Isochronous), 600 bytes
children.name: USB_HOST_HW_BUFFER_BIAS
children.title: Hardware FIFO size biasing

children.help:
On connection of a USB device, the USB 2.0 specification requires a "debounce interval with a minimum
duration of 100ms" to allow the connection to stabilize (see USB 2.0 chapter 7.1.7.3 for more details).
During the debounce interval, no new connection/disconnection events are registered.

The default value is set to 250 ms to be safe.
children.name: USB_HOST_DEBOUNCE_DELAY_MS
children.title: Debounce delay in ms

children.help:
The reset signaling can be generated on any Hub or Host Controller port by request from the USB System
Software. The USB 2.0 specification requires that "the reset signaling must be driven for a minimum of
10ms" (see USB 2.0 chapter 7.1.7.5 for more details).  After the reset, the hub port will transition to
the Enabled state (refer to Section 11.5).

The default value is set to 30 ms to be safe.
children.name: USB_HOST_RESET_HOLD_MS
children.title: Reset hold in ms

children.help:
After a port stops driving the reset signal, the USB 2.0 specification requires that the "USB System
Software guarantees a minimum of 10 ms for reset recovery" before the attached device is expected to
respond to data transfers (see USB 2.0 chapter 7.1.7.3 for more details). The device may ignore any
data transfers during the recovery interval.

The default value is set to 30 ms to be safe.
children.name: USB_HOST_RESET_RECOVERY_MS
children.title: Reset recovery delay in ms

children.help:
"After successful completion of the Status stage, the device is allowed a SetAddress() recovery
interval of 2 ms. At the end of this interval, the device must be able to accept Setup packets
addressed to the new address. Also, at the end of the recovery interval, the device must not respond to
tokens sent to the old address (unless, of course, the old and new address is the same)." See USB 2.0
chapter 9.2.6.3 for more details.

The default value is set to 10 ms to be safe.
children.name: USB_HOST_SET_ADDR_RECOVERY_MS
children.title: SetAddress() recovery time in ms

children.help:
If enabled, the following functions are provided by the VFS component.

stat, link, unlink, rename, utime, access, truncate, rmdir, mkdir,
opendir, closedir, readdir, readdir_r, seekdir, telldir, rewinddir

Filesystem drivers can then be registered to handle these functions
for specific paths.

Disabling this option can save memory when the support for these functions
is not required.
children.name: VFS_SUPPORT_DIR
children.title: Provide directory related functions

children.help:
Select() related functions might produce an unconveniently lot of
debug outputs when one sets the default log level to DEBUG or higher.
It is possible to suppress these debug outputs by enabling this
option.
children.name: VFS_SUPPRESS_SELECT_DEBUG_OUTPUT
children.title: Suppress select() related debug outputs

children.help:
If enabled, select function is provided by the VFS component, and can be used
on peripheral file descriptors (such as UART) and sockets at the same time.

If disabled, the default select implementation will be provided by LWIP for
sockets only.

Disabling this option can reduce code size if support for "select" on UART file
descriptors is not required.
children.name: VFS_SUPPORT_SELECT
children.title: Provide select function

children.help: Disabling this option can save memory when the support for termios.h is not required.
children.name: VFS_SUPPORT_TERMIOS
children.title: Provide termios.h functions

children.help: Define maximum number of virtual filesystems that can be registered.
children.name: VFS_MAX_COUNT
children.title: Maximum Number of Virtual Filesystems

children.help: Define maximum number of host filesystem mount points.
children.name: VFS_SEMIHOSTFS_MAX_MOUNT_POINTS
children.title: Host FS: Maximum number of the host filesystem mount points

children.help:
If enabled, the following functions are provided by the VFS component.

open, close, read, write, pread, pwrite, lseek, fstat, fsync, ioctl, fcntl

Filesystem drivers can then be registered to handle these functions
for specific paths.

Disabling this option can save memory when the support for these functions
is not required.

Note that the following functions can still be used with socket file descriptors
when this option is disabled:

close, read, write, ioctl, fcntl.
children.name: VFS_SUPPORT_IO
children.title: Provide basic I/O functions

children.help:
Sector size used by wear levelling library.
You can set default sector size or size that will
fit to the flash device sector size.

With sector size set to 4096 bytes, wear levelling library is more
efficient. However if FAT filesystem is used on top of wear levelling
library, it will need more temporary storage: 4096 bytes for each
mounted filesystem and 4096 bytes for each opened file.

With sector size set to 512 bytes, wear levelling library will perform
more operations with flash memory, but less RAM will be used by FAT
filesystem library (512 bytes for the filesystem and 512 bytes for each
file opened).
children.name: WL_SECTOR_SIZE
children.title: Wear Levelling library sector size

children.help:
Specify the mode to store data into flash:

- In Performance mode a data will be stored to the RAM and then
  stored back to the flash. Compared to the Safety mode, this operation is
  faster, but if power will be lost when erase sector operation is in
  progress, then the data from complete flash device sector will be lost.

- In Safety mode data from complete flash device sector will be read from
  flash, modified, and then stored back to flash.
  Compared to the Performance mode, this operation is slower, but if
  power is lost during erase sector operation, then the data from full
  flash device sector will not be lost.
children.name: WL_SECTOR_MODE
children.title: Sector store mode

children.help: This sets the maximum number of entries of Wi-Fi scan results that will be kept by the provisioning manager
children.name: WIFI_PROV_SCAN_MAX_ENTRIES
children.title: Max Wi-Fi Scan Result Entries

children.help:
Time (in seconds) after which the Wi-Fi provisioning manager will auto-stop after connecting to
a Wi-Fi network successfully.
children.name: WIFI_PROV_AUTOSTOP_TIMEOUT
children.title: Provisioning auto-stop timeout

children.help: This option is applicable only when provisioning transport is BLE.
children.name: WIFI_PROV_BLE_BONDING
children.title: Enable BLE bonding

children.help: Used to enable Secure connection support when provisioning transport is BLE.
children.name: WIFI_PROV_BLE_SEC_CONN
children.title: Enable BLE Secure connection flag

children.help: Used to enforce link encryption when attempting to read / write characteristic
children.name: WIFI_PROV_BLE_FORCE_ENCRYPTION
children.title: Force Link Encryption during characteristic Read / Write

children.name: WIFI_PROV_DISCONNECT_AFTER_PROV
children.title: Terminate connection after provisioning is done

children.name: WIFI_PROV_KEEP_BLE_ON_AFTER_PROV
children.title: Keep BT on after provisioning is done

children.help: Scan will end after scanning the entire channel. This option is useful in Mesh WiFi Systems.
children.name: WIFI_PROV_STA_ALL_CHANNEL_SCAN
children.title: All Channel Scan

children.help: Scan will end after an AP matching with the SSID has been detected.
children.name: WIFI_PROV_STA_FAST_SCAN
children.title: Fast Scan

help:
By enabling this option, ESP-IDF experimental feature options will be visible.

Note you should still enable a certain experimental feature option to use it, and you
should read the corresponding risk warning and known issue list carefully.
name: IDF_EXPERIMENTAL_FEATURES
title: Make experimental features visible
